intro: Ranunculus aquatilis var. saniculifolius, commonly known as the water crowfoot, is a aquatic or semi-aquatic plant native to temperate regions. It typically grows in shallow water, along the edges of ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams. The plant features finely divided, feather-like leaves that float on the water surface or emerge from the water. Its flowers are usually yellow or white, with five petals and numerous stamens. It plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various aquatic organisms.
